title: Add --export-theme-colors CLI flag to export complete theme color definitions
body:
This PR adds a new `--export-theme-colors` CLI flag to VS Code that exports all theme color definitions with their default values to a JSON file, providing theme developers with a complete source of truth for all available color keys.

## Problem

Theme developers currently lack a comprehensive, machine-readable reference for all VS Code theme colors and their default values across different theme variants (light, dark, high contrast). This makes it difficult to create complete themes and understand what colors are available for customization.

## Solution

The new `--export-theme-colors` flag extracts all registered colors from VS Code's internal color registry and outputs them in a structured JSON format.

**Usage:**
```bash
# Export to file
code --export-theme-colors theme-colors.json

# Export to stdout  
code --export-theme-colors
```

**Output format:**
```json
{
  "version": "1.0",
  "generated": "2025-09-19T19:00:05.290Z",
  "description": "Complete VS Code theme color definitions with default values",
  "totalColors": 400+,
  "colors": {
    "editor.background": {
      "description": "Editor background color.",
      "needsTransparency": false,
      "defaults": {
        "light": "#FFFFFF",
        "dark": "#1E1E1E",
        "hcDark": "#000000",
        "hcLight": "#FFFFFF"
      }
    },
    "focusBorder": {
      "description": "Overall border color for focused elements.",
      "needsTransparency": false,
      "defaults": {
        "light": "#0078d4",
        "dark": "#007FD4",
        "hcDark": "#f38518", 
        "hcLight": "#0f4a85"
      }
    }
    // ... all other colors
  }
}
```

## Implementation Details

- **CLI Integration**: Added to existing CLI argument parsing and help system
- **Complete Coverage**: Imports all color registration files to ensure no colors are missed
- **Rich Metadata**: Includes descriptions, transparency requirements, and deprecation status
- **Theme Variants**: Provides default values for light, dark, high contrast dark, and high contrast light themes
- **Error Handling**: Gracefully handles different color value types and missing defaults

## Benefits

- **Complete Reference**: Theme developers get all ~400+ VS Code colors in one place
- **Accurate Defaults**: Default values directly from VS Code's source code
- **Machine Readable**: JSON format enables automation and tooling
- **Always Current**: Reflects the exact colors available in the VS Code version being used
- **Developer Friendly**: Clear descriptions and structured format for easy consumption

This addresses the need for a "100% complete source of truth" for VS Code theme development as requested by the community.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT SUFFIX -->

Created from VS Code via the [GitHub Pull Request](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github) extension.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->

title: Fix QuickInput right arrow navigation by properly setting InputFocusedContext
body:
Fixes the issue where right arrow key navigation doesn't work in QuickInput when using Monaco editor, as reported in [microsoft/monaco-editor#4918](https://github.com/microsoft/monaco-editor/issues/4918).

## Problem

The right arrow key in QuickInput was always triggering "accept" instead of cursor navigation when the input was focused but the cursor wasn't at the end. This broke basic text editing functionality in Monaco editor environments.

The issue was in the keybinding condition for right arrow in `quickInputActions.ts`:

```typescript
when: ContextKeyExpr.or(InputFocusedContext.negate(), endOfQuickInputBoxContext)
```

This means right arrow triggers "accept" when:
- `InputFocusedContext` is false (input not focused) OR 
- `endOfQuickInputBoxContext` is true (cursor at end)

However, `InputFocusedContext` was never being set to `true` when the QuickInput's input gained focus, causing the right arrow to always trigger accept behavior.

## Solution

**Added proper InputFocusedContext management to QuickInputController:**

1. **Context Key Binding**: Added `InputFocusedContext.bindTo(contextKeyService)` in the constructor
2. **Focus Event Handling**: Added event handlers to set the context when input gains/loses focus:
   ```typescript
   this._register(inputBox.onDidFocus(() => {
       this.inputFocusedContext.set(true);
   }));
   this._register(inputBox.onDidBlur(() => {
       this.inputFocusedContext.set(false);
   }));
   ```
3. **API Exposure**: Added `onDidFocus` and `onDidBlur` getters to `QuickInputBox` to expose the underlying `HistoryInputBox` focus events

## Expected Behavior After Fix

- **Input focused, cursor not at end**: Right arrow **navigates** (moves cursor)
- **Input focused, cursor at end**: Right arrow **accepts** 
- **Input not focused**: Right arrow **accepts**

This restores the intended behavior where users can navigate within the input text using arrow keys, while still allowing convenient accept-on-right-arrow when the cursor is at the end or when navigating the list.

## Testing

Added test coverage to verify that focus/blur events are properly exposed and can be observed, ensuring the event wiring works correctly.

Fixes microsoft/monaco-editor#4918

title: Fix GitHub authentication PKCE flow for web environments
body:
Fixes GitHub OAuth authentication failure in web environments (insiders.vscode.dev) caused by incorrect mixing of OAuth 2.0 authentication methods.

## Problem

Users were unable to authenticate with GitHub in insiders.vscode.dev, receiving the error:
```
Sign in failed: Error: No auth flow succeeded.
A code_verifier was not included, but the authorization request included a code_challenge. 
Codes requested with a code_challenge MUST be redeemed with a code_verifier.
```

The issue occurred because the `exchangeCodeForToken` function was incorrectly sending both `client_secret` and `code_verifier` parameters in the token exchange request. According to OAuth 2.0 and GitHub's PKCE implementation:

- **Public clients** (web apps) should use PKCE with `code_verifier` but **no** `client_secret`  
- **Confidential clients** (desktop apps) should use `client_secret` but **no** PKCE
- Mixing both approaches violates the OAuth 2.0 specification

Additionally, the `UrlHandlerFlow` was configured with `supportsNoClientSecret: false`, preventing it from being used in web environments where no client secret is available.

## Solution

**Updated UrlHandlerFlow configuration:**
- Changed `supportsNoClientSecret` from `false` to `true` to enable PKCE-based authentication in web environments

**Fixed token exchange logic:**
- Modified `exchangeCodeForToken` to conditionally use the appropriate OAuth 2.0 flow:
  - When `client_secret` is available (desktop): Use traditional OAuth with `client_secret` 
  - When `client_secret` is NOT available (web): Use PKCE with `code_verifier`
- Added explicit `grant_type: authorization_code` parameter for OAuth 2.0 compliance

**Added test coverage:**
- Created test case to verify `UrlHandlerFlow` works correctly without a client secret

## Testing

- ✅ TypeScript compilation passes
- ✅ Manual testing confirms correct OAuth parameter selection for both environments
- ✅ Flow selection testing verifies `UrlHandlerFlow` availability in web worker contexts
- ✅ Backward compatibility maintained for desktop VS Code

This fix resolves GitHub authentication in insiders.vscode.dev while preserving existing desktop authentication functionality.

Fixes microsoft/vscode#267120

title: Feature Request: Add setting to configure default chat mode
body:
## Summary

Add a VS Code setting to allow users to configure which chat mode (Ask, Edit, Agent, or custom chatmode) should be selected by default when opening the Chat view.

## Motivation

Currently, VS Code always defaults to one of the built-in chat modes when opening the Chat view. Users who frequently use custom chat modes (defined via `.chatmode.md` files) must manually select their preferred mode from the dropdown every time they start a new chat session. This creates friction for users who have invested time in creating specialized chat modes tailored to their workflows.

## Proposed Solution

Add a new setting such as:

```json
{
  "chat.defaultMode": "Beast"
}
```

This setting would:
- Accept values: `"ask"`, `"edit"`, `"agent"`, or the name of any available custom chat mode
- Default to current behavior if not specified
- Apply when opening the Chat view or starting a new chat session
- Work with both the Chat view UI and command line `code chat` invocations (unless `-m/--mode` is explicitly specified)

## Current Workarounds

Users currently must:
1. Manually select their preferred mode from the dropdown each time
2. Use command line with `-m/--mode` flag for individual sessions (but this doesn't persist)
3. Create shell aliases like `alias beast='code chat -m Beast'`

## Additional Context

- Custom chat modes are defined using `.chatmode.md` files with YAML frontmatter
- The command line already supports `-m/--mode` for per-session mode selection
- This would enhance the user experience for teams and individuals who have invested in custom chat modes
- Similar to how VS Code allows setting default formatters, debuggers, etc.

## Impact

This feature would:
- Reduce friction for users with custom chat modes
- Encourage adoption of custom chat modes
- Improve workflow efficiency for AI-assisted development

title: Source Control: Cannot commit no-diff merge resolution when other modified tracked files are unstaged
body:
Type: Bug ### **Bug Report** **Title:** Source Control: Cannot commit no-diff merge resolution when other modified tracked files are unstaged **Issue Type:** Bug **Description:** When resolving a merge conflict, if the final state of the resolved file is identical to `HEAD` (the current branch's version), the VS Code Source Control GUI incorrectly prevents the user from committing the merge, **specifically when there is at least one other *tracked* file with unstaged modifications.** The GUI's logic appears to be overridden by the presence of the unstaged file. It defaults to the standard "commit" workflow, sees the unstaged changes, and insists that the user stage them before committing. It fails to recognize that the primary task is to finalize the merge, which should be allowed while leaving the other file's unstaged modifications in the working directory. This blocks a common workflow and forces the user to the command line to run `git commit` which correctly finalizes the merge and preserves the unstaged changes. **Steps to Reproduce:** 1. Create a new folder and open it in VS Code. Initialize a Git repository. ```bash mkdir merge-bug-repro && cd merge-bug-repro git init git config user.name "Test" && git config user.email "test@example.com" ``` 2. Create and commit two files, so both are tracked by Git. ```bash echo "line 1\nline 2\nline 3" > test.txt echo "This is another file." > another_file.txt git add . git commit -m "Initial commit with two files" ``` 3. Create a feature branch and modify `test.txt`. ```bash git checkout -b my-feature-branch echo "line 1\nUPDATED ON BRANCH\nline 3" > test.txt git commit -am "Update line 2 on feature branch" ``` 4. Switch back to `main` and create a conflicting change in `test.txt`. ```bash git checkout main echo "line 1\nUPDATED ON MAIN\nline 3" > test.txt git commit -am "Update line 2 on main" ``` 5. Switch back to the feature branch to prepare for the merge. ```bash git checkout my-feature-branch ``` 6. **Crucially, modify the *other tracked file* but do not stage it.** ```bash echo "This file has been modified but is not staged." > another_file.txt ``` 7. Attempt to merge `main` into your feature branch. ```bash git merge main # This correctly reports a merge conflict in test.txt. # another_file.txt remains as a modified, unstaged file. ``` 8. Resolve the conflict in `test.txt` by choosing the version from your current branch (the no-diff resolution). ```bash echo "line 1\nUPDATED ON BRANCH\nline 3" > test.txt ``` 9. Stage the resolved file to mark the conflict as resolved. ```bash git add test.txt ``` 10. Go to the **Source Control** panel in VS Code. **Actual Behavior:** The Source Control panel shows `another_file.txt` in the "Changes" list. The "Commit" button has been replaced with a "Continue" button. If you click on it, you get the message shown on the following screenshot. So I click "Cancel" since I don't want to stage `another_file.txt` and I don't want to click Always/Never to alter the default behavior. **Expected Behavior:** Clicking "Continue" would directly create the merge commit to finalize the merge process. The another_file.txt file should remain in the "Changes" list as a modified, unstaged file, and the repository should successfully exit the merging state. git version 2.47.0.windows.2 VS Code version: Code 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes: Remote OS version: Linux x64 5.15.0-151-generic

title: [Bug] Unable to navigate with right arrow in QuickInput in Monaco

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

Navigating within a `QuickInput`'s input box with the right arrow key doesn't work in monaco-editor due to a missing context key value that should indicate that the input element is focused. I originally reported the issue in the monaco-editor repository, but implementing a fix requires changes in the core.

Full details and root cause analysis are in the original issue: https://github.com/microsoft/monaco-editor/issues/4918

title: Parts List with Shopping Links for Upcycling Fridge to Greenhouse

labels.name: invalid
labels.description: Issue identified as not relevant or not valid

body:
Create a comprehensive parts list (with links) for converting an old refrigerator into a greenhouse with hydroponic elements, as described below. The list should be suitable for inclusion in a Word document and include affordable, reliable product suggestions for each major component, with direct shopping links (Amazon or similar).

**Requirements:**
- Submersible water pump for 7–9 tubes/basins, capable of lifting water 3–4 feet.
- Heating mats (waterproof, plug-in) for under trays, with temperature controller.
- Full spectrum LED grow lights (6 per shelf, 2 shelves).
- Heat lamp (ceramic emitter or infrared) above water bin, plus clamp fixture.
- Aquarium air pump & air stone for humidity and water oxygenation.
- Timers for automating lights, pumps, mats, etc.
- Temperature & humidity controllers/meters for climate regulation (freezer section).
- pH/EC meter (optional for hydroponics).
- Miscellaneous: power strips, extension cords, tubing, waterproof trays, zip ties, silicone sealant.

**Sample Product List:**
- [VIVOSUN 400GPH Submersible Pump](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07JZV24HV)
- [VIVOSUN Seedling Heat Mat](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B017PD6TB8)
- [Inkbird Heat Mat Thermostat Controller](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B015F4VFGI)
- [Barrina T5 LED Grow Light 6-Pack](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07Q2H1M3X)
- [Simple Deluxe 150W Ceramic Heat Emitter](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07D1CZ1T6)
- [Simple Deluxe Clamp Lamp Fixture](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01E9IY6US)
- [Tetra Whisper Air Pump 10-30 Gal](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0009YF4FI)
- [Uxcell Aquarium Air Stones](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00SWF4N3G)
- [BN-LINK 24 Hour Mechanical Timer](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01LPSGBZS)
- [Inkbird ITC-308 Digital Temp Controller](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B011296704)
- [Inkbird Humidity Controller IHC200](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07PQ2YWXF)
- [Govee Thermometer Hygrometer](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07R586J37)
- [Apera Instruments pH20 Tester Kit](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01ENFOHN8)

The list should be formatted for easy copy-paste into Word and include all links. Include a note about setup tips and possible substitutions for budget/performance.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disable `html.suggest.html5` in settings
2. Create an html file, add a start tag (e.g. `<body>`) and watch vscode suggest `/body` when opening a second tag.

title: Copilot chat no longer surfaces MCP tool progress

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
### Summary

MCP tool progress used to surface in the Copilot chat transcript after the work in microsoft/vscode#244754 (commit 38768712a38, “chat: allow tools to report progress”). Recent follow-up work removed the plumbing that connected those progress notifications to the UI. As a result, MCP servers that emit `notifications/progress` (for example XcodeBuildMCP) no longer show any inline progress in Copilot chat—even though the server-side notifications arrive and are processed by the language-model tooling layer.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Run an MCP server that streams progress (e.g. XcodeBuildMCP).
2. Register it in VS Code / Copilot chat and invoke a long-running tool (`build_sim`, `build_device`, etc.).
3. Watch Copilot chat (Insiders build with proposed APIs enabled) during the invocation.

### Expected Result
Progress messages emitted via `notifications/progress` should appear in the chat transcript (as they did right after microsoft/vscode#244754 landed).

### Actual Result
No progress UI is shown. The tool call only renders its final result once the MCP command finishes, leaving the user with no feedback while it runs.

### Investigation
- commit 38768712a38 (“chat: allow tools to report progress”) wired `ILanguageModelToolsService` to surface progress into the workbench and chat UI.
- commit edc8644253dc87ee322ace9dd9e94d3111d2afe4 removed `languageModelToolProgressService.ts`, the custom progress location, and the plumbing in `ChatToolInvocationPart` that listened for those updates.
- follow-up commit 41cc1e28362b0511ac7c39ff42fe1bafc27c4e71 simplified the progress payload shape but still never restored the UI hook.

Today the progress events make it as far as `LanguageModelToolsService.acceptProgress(...)`, but nothing downstream updates the Copilot chat view. Users therefore get no progress feedback despite MCP servers emitting it.

### Request
Please restore MCP tool progress rendering in Copilot chat (or provide an alternative surface) so that `notifications/progress` from MCP servers are visible to users again.

title: OS-Level Notifications for VSCode Tasks Completion

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

labels.name: unreleased
labels.description: Patch has not yet been released in VS Code Insiders

body: ## Summary I would like to suggest adding OS-level notifications to VSCode that alert users when long-running [tasks](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/debugtest/tasks) complete execution. This would significantly improve the developer experience by allowing users to multitask while waiting for builds, tests, or other time-consuming operations to finish. ## Problem Statement For example, my Expo app build process (`eas build --local --platform ios`) currently takes approximately 8 minutes to complete. During this time, I often need to: - Read documentation - Write some Jira 🤭 tickets - Review code in other applications - etc Without OS-level notifications, I frequently miss when builds complete, leading to inefficient workflow and lost productivity. ## Proposed Solution Add native OS-level notification support for VSCode [Tasks](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/debugtest/tasks) completion, including: - Show system notifications when any VSCode task finishes (success, failure, or cancellation) - Support all task types: builds, tests, npm scripts, terminal commands, AI Agent operations - Configurable settings to enable/disable and customize notifications ## Motivation This feature would be particularly valuable for: - **Build Processes**: Long-running compilation and build tasks - **Test Suites**: Comprehensive test runs that may take several minutes - **AI Agent Operations**: As mentioned in [community discussions](https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/157286#discussioncomment-13372951), users find OS notifications "extremely valuable" for AI agents that can take "30 seconds to 5 minutes or more to complete each task." Although this example is for AI agent tasks, it is also applicable to npm tasks. - **Custom Scripts**: Any long-running npm scripts or custom automation ## Benefits - **Improved Productivity**: Developers can multitask without losing track of running processes - **Better User Experience**: Reduces the need to constantly monitor task progress - **Cross-Application Awareness**: Notifications work even when VSCode is not the active application. Example: [Notifications](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-capabilities/common-capabilities#display-notifications), which displays brief information in the bottom right of VS Code. However, these notifications cannot be seen if VSCode is not focused. - **Consistency**: Aligns with modern development tools and user expectations ## Related Work - [Feature Request: Audio Notifications for GitHub Copilot Agent Mode](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/250915) - While this was closed as not planned, visual notifications may be more universally useful than audio - VSCode forks like Cursor already implement similar notification features for AI agent completion

title: support MarkdownString in TerminalLink.tooltip and DocumentLink.tooltip
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I would like to use a [MarkdownString](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#MarkdownString) in `TerminalLink.tooltip` ([TerminalLink](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#TerminalLink)) and `DocumentLink.tooltip` ([DocumentLink](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#DocumentLink)), similar to [Hover](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#Hover).

Like:
```ts
tooltip?: string | MarkdownString;
```

title: How to restore has been checked "No more notice"?
body: VSCode notifications in the lower right corner,I checked "No more notice",I don't know how to recover

title: fix: updates quickInputBox aria role to combobox
body:
Changes quickInputBox aria role from textbox to combobox. Combobox is more appropriate since it follows the a11y pattern of having a popup and controls a list. Attempts to improve communication with the screen reader by providing a more appropriate aria role.

Fixes: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/267445

## Steps to Test:
1. Checkout the PR: git checkout <branch-name>

2. Rebuild and Run the Project: Follow the standard process for building the project and launching the IDE.

3. Enable a screen reader: Turn on a screen reader on your operating system (e.g., VoiceOver on macOS, NVDA on Windows, or ChromeVox on ChromeOS).

4. Open the Quick Input Dialog: Use the keyboard shortcut to open the "Search Workspaces" or "Open File" dialog (e.g., Cmd+Shift+P or Cmd+P).

5. Verify the ARIA Role: Focus the search input field and listen to the screen reader's announcement. It should now announce the input as a "combobox" or something similar, confirming that the ARIA role has been correctly updated.

6. Test Functionality: Ensure that the core functionality of the input still works as expected. Verify that you can still type to filter the list of suggestions, use the arrow keys to navigate the list, and press Enter to select an item.

title: Accessibility/A11y: quickInputBox aria role is textbox when it should be combobox
body:
## Description
When opening the "Search Workspaces" dialog (which has the placeholder "Search files"), the input is incorrectly announced as a "text field" by screen readers like VoiceOver and ChromeVox. The component's functionality—an input that filters a list of selectable items—is that of a `combobox`. However, its ARIA `role` is set to `textbox`.

This semantic mismatch creates confusion for screen reader users who expect to interact with a control that supports both text input and list navigation. The screen reader's announcement does not accurately reflect the element's purpose, leading to a poor user experience.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Enable a screen reader (e.g., VoiceOver on macOS or ChromeVox on ChromeOS).

2. Activate the "Search icon + Workspace" input in the middle navigation.

3. **Expected:** The screen reader should announce the input as a "combobox" or similar, indicating its autosuggest functionality.

4. **Observed:** The screen reader announces the input as a "text field," "edit text," or "text box," which is semantically incorrect for this interactive component.

## Expected Behavior:
The input field for the "Search files by name" in the dialog should have an ARIA role of `combobox`. This change would ensure that screen readers correctly identify the element's purpose, allowing users to immediately understand that they can both type to filter a list and use the keyboard to navigate and select from it.

This is in line with the WAI-ARIA Authoring Practices for a [Combobox with Listbox Pop-up](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/combobox/).

## User Impact:
This issue negatively impacts users who rely on screen readers and individuals with cognitive disabilities. Mislabeling the component can cause:

* **Disorientation:** Users are not immediately aware of the input's full functionality.
* **Inefficient Navigation:** Users may not realize they can use arrow keys to navigate the list of file suggestions, instead of relying on a keyboard-only search.
* **Inconsistent Experience:** The behavior differs from other, correctly implemented comboboxes on the web, leading to confusion and a less predictable user interface.

## Proposed Solution
The fix for this bug is to change the ARIA `role` attribute of the input element from `textbox` to `combobox` in the QuickInputService implementation. This is a framework-level change that will affect all components that use the QuickPick API. By making this change, all future and existing quick-pick dialogs will be semantically correct.

The file that needs to be updated is likely `src/vs/base/browser/ui/quickinput/quickInputBox.ts`, specifically in the code that creates the input element.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104 and 1.104.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 22H2

Steps to Reproduce:

The new versions 1.104 and 1.104.1 lead to CPU usage reaching 80% to 100%. Even when I minimize the VS Code window, CPU usage occasionally spikes above 80%. From the processes, it appears to be the rg process. However, I had already disabled "Search Editor: Focus Results On Search" back in version 1.103. Moreover, when the window is minimized, it should not continuously consume CPU in the background. After reverting to version 1.103.2, everything returns to normal. I can only temporarily disable the upgrade; please investigate why rg is consuming such high CPU resources.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently these editor actions exist: `View: Pin Editor` and `View: Unpin Editor`, however there is no action to toggle pinning/unpinning an editor. This feature request is for the new action `View: Toggle Pin Editor`.
